description: Mere ownership effect is the phenomenon that people tend to value what they own more than what they do not own. Assumes that ownership of an object causes the owner to treat the object as a social entity because ownership creates a psychological association between the object and the owner.
tags: ownership; mere ownership effect; psychological ownership; valuing

description: Two experiments (specifically study 2 in this case) investigated the effect of exposure to words related to hot temperatures on aggressive thoughts. Participants exposed to hot temperature words showed increased aggression in both experiments, compared to those exposed to cold or neutral words. This suggests a strong connection in memory between hot temperature words and aggressive thoughts and perceptions.
tags: Priming
ref_original: C. Nathan DeWall, Brad J. Bushman, Hot under the collar in a lukewarm environment: Words associated with hot temperature increase aggressive thoughts and hostile perceptions, Journal of Experimental Social Psychology, Volume 45, Issue 4, 2009, Pages 1045-1047, ISSN 0022-1031,
ref_replication: Randy J. McCarthy, Close replication attempts of the heat priming-hostile perception effect, Journal of Experimental Social Psychology, Volume 54, 2014, Pages 165-169, ISSN 0022-1031,

description: High-power posers experienced elevations in testosterone, decreases in cortisol, and increased feelings of power and tolerance for risk; low-power posers exhibited the opposite pattern.
tags: cortisol, embodiment, hormones, neuroendocrinology, nonverbal behavior, power, risk taking, testosterone
ref_original: Carney, D. R., Cuddy, A. J. C., & Yap, A. J. (2010). Power Posing: Brief Nonverbal Displays Affect Neuroendocrine Levels and Risk Tolerance. Psychological Science, 21(10), 1363-1368.
ref_replication: Ranehill, E., Dreber, A., Johannesson, M., Leiberg, S., Sul, S., & Weber, R. A. (2015). Assessing the Robustness of Power Posing: No Effect on Hormones and Risk Tolerance in a Large Sample of Men and Women. Psychological Science, 26(5), 653-656.

ref_original: Carney, D. R., Cuddy, A. J., & Yap, A. J. (2010). Power posing: Brief nonverbal displays affect neuroendocrine levels and risk tolerance. Psychological science, 21(10), 1363-1368.
ref_replication: Garrison, K., Tang, D., & Schmeichel, B. J. (2016). Embodying power. Social Psychological and Personality Science, 7(7), 623–630.

ref_original: Carney, D. R., Cuddy, A. J., & Yap, A. J. (2010). Power posing: Brief nonverbal displays affect neuroendocrine levels and risk tolerance. Psychological science, 21(10), 1363-1368.
ref_replication: Ranehill, E., Dreber, A., Johannesson, M., Leiberg, S., Sul, S., & Weber, R. A. (2015). Assessing the robustness of power posing. Psychological Science, 26(5), 653–656.

description: Deleting memories of experiential purchases (vs. material purchases) have a greater impact on their self-concept (H4), participants perceive experiential purchase as more satisfying than material purchase.
tags: CORE, Judgment, Decision Making, JDM, Heuristics, Biases
ref_original: Carter, T. J., & Gilovich, T. (2012). I am what I do, not what I have: the differential centrality of experiential and material purchases to the self. Journal of personality and social psychology, 102(6), 1304.
ref_replication: Eva Yiyu Chen, Michelle Xingyu Chee, Gilad Feldman; Revisiting the Differential Centrality of Experiential and Material Purchases to the Self: Replication and Extension of Carter and Gilovich (2012). Collabra: Psychology 3 January 2023; 9 (1): 57785. doi:

description: Deletion of experiential purchases memories is considered as having a bigger impact on self-concept than deletion of material purchases memories. participants were more unwilling to change memories of experiential purchase than material purchase.
tags: CORE, Judgment, Decision Making, JDM, Heuristics, Biases
ref_original: Carter, T. J., & Gilovich, T. (2012). I am what I do, not what I have: the differential centrality of experiential and material purchases to the self. Journal of personality and social psychology, 102(6), 1304.
ref_replication: Eva Yiyu Chen, Michelle Xingyu Chee, Gilad Feldman; Revisiting the Differential Centrality of Experiential and Material Purchases to the Self: Replication and Extension of Carter and Gilovich (2012). Collabra: Psychology 3 January 2023; 9 (1): 57785. doi:

description: Knowledge of new others’ experiential purchases is perceived as providing greater insight than new others’ material purchases (such as when getting to know someone new).
tags: CORE, Judgment, Decision Making, JDM, Heuristics, Biases

description: Knowledge of a stranger’s experiential purchases is perceived as providing greater insight into the stranger’s true self than knowledge of the stranger’s material purchases.

description: This research explores how individuals seek to compensate for a lack of social connections by forming human-like bonds with nonhuman agents, such as animals and gadgets, or by strengthening beliefs in anthropomorphized religious figures like God. Through three studies, evidence shows this behavior in people experiencing chronic loneliness and those made to feel temporarily lonely, while also demonstrating that such compensatory actions are specific to loneliness rather than general negative emotions. These findings shed light on the circumstances under which people are more likely to attribute human characteristics to nonhuman entities and the reverse process of dehumanization.
ref_original: Epley, N., Akalis, S., Waytz, A., & Cacioppo, J. T. (2008). Creating Social Connection Through Inferential Reproduction: Loneliness and Perceived Agency in Gadgets, Gods, and Greyhounds. Psychological Science, 19(2), 114-120.
ref_replication: Epley, N., Akalis, S., Waytz, A., & Cacioppo, J. T. (2008). Creating social connection through inferential reproduction: Loneliness and perceived agency in gadgets, Gods, and greyhounds.

description: saving a portion of lives near the end of a crisis would be valued more highly than saving an equal portion near the beginning of a crisis because the former solves virtually all the problem whereas the latter does not

ref_replication: Hagger, M. S., Wood, C., Stiff, C., & Chatzisarantis, N. L. D. (2010). Ego depletion and the strength model of self-control: A meta-analysis. Psychological Bulletin, 136(4), 495–525.

description: Self-control relies on glucose as a limited energy source. A single act of self-control causes glucose to drop below optimal levels, thereby impairing subsequent attempts at self-control.
tags: Self-control, glucose

description: Experiment 1. Experiment 1 in the study by Nina Mazar, On Amir, and Dan Ariely investigated the effect of moral reminders on honesty. Participants were assigned to recall either ten books they read in high school or the Ten Commandments before completing a task where they could cheat. The study found that recalling the Ten Commandments eliminated cheating completely, while participants who recalled the books cheated when given the opportunity.
tags: Priming
ref_original: Mazar, N., Amir, O., & Ariely, D. (2008). The Dishonesty of Honest People: A Theory of Self-Concept Maintenance. Journal of Marketing Research, 45(6), 633-644. Experiment 1
ref_replication: Verschuere B, Meijer EH, Jim A, et al. Registered Replication Report on Mazar, Amir, and Ariely (2008). Advances in Methods and Practices in Psychological Science. 2018;1(3):299-317. Total combined data

description: By manipulating the timing of an activity, the Time-Elicit (TEL) procedure of stating the maximum amount of hours required for a task should be more sensitive to a change in time scarcity, because time of money required for a task). Analogously, the TEL procedure should be more sensitive to a change in the timing of the activity. That is, distant activitiesscarcity receives a higher weight in TEL vs. Money-Elicit (MEL) procedure - stating the minimum amount should yield lower wage rates, particularly in the TEL (vs. MEL) procedure, which should diminish the wage rate asymmetry
tags: time, money, scarcity, time-money tradeoffs, wage rates, procedural invariance

description: If you are uncertain about your own self-concept, then you will not want to introduce even more uncertainty by altering your identity. Consumers with “low self-concept clarity” should therefore be more motivated to keep their identities stable by (1) retaining products that are relevant to their identities, and (2) choosing not to acquire new products that are relevant to their identities.
tags: self-concept clarity, subscription services, self-signaling, retention choice, self-concept structure, identity signaling
ref_original: Savary, J., Dhar, R.K., JoharEditor, G.V., & InmanEditor, J.J. (2020). The Uncertain Self: How Self-Concept Structure Affects Subscription Choice. Journal of Consumer Research. Study 4
ref_replication: Simmons, J. &. Nelson, L.D. (2020). [84] Data Replicada #3: Does Self-Concept Uncertainty Influence Magazine Subscription Choice? Data Colada. https://datacolada.org/84

ref_original: Schnall, S., Benton, J., & Harvey, S. (2008). With a clean conscience: Cleanliness reduces the severity of moral judgments. Psychological science, 19(12), 1219-1222.
ref_replication: Ton, B., Harris, A., Clah, E., Koenig, B., Walker, A., Leukel, P. J., … Riddle, R. (2018, December 12). Schnall and Johnson Student Replication  (2018).

description: After watching a disgust-evoking video, composite moral judgements were less severe in the hand-washing condition as compared to the no-hand-washing condition.
contributors: Patric Justin Leukel, Alexander Jordan, Marcie Sharp, Jeremiah Ki Fat, Jeremy Chaves, Bryan Koenig
ref_original: Schnall, S., Benton, J., & Harvey, S. (2008). With a clean conscience: Cleanliness reduces the severity of moral judgments. Psychological science, 19(12), 1219-1222.
ref_replication: Leukel, P. J., Jordan, A., Sharp, M., Fat, J. K., Chaves, J., & Koenig, B. (2018, May 2). Influence of Cleanliness on Moral Judgements: A Direct Replication of Schnall, Benton, and Harvey  (2008).

description: Physical purity (cleanliness) makes moral judgments less severe, by comparing composite moral judgment scores across a hand-washing condition and a non hand-washing condition.
contributors: Garth Frehner, Jaden Aiona, Walker Sickler, Brakkon Garrett, Kaitlin Lawler, Melissa Benavides, Bryan Koenig, Luke Poulter
ref_original: Schnall, S., Benton, J., & Harvey, S. (2008). With a clean conscience: Cleanliness reduces the severity of moral judgments. Psychological science, 19(12), 1219-1222.
ref_replication: Frehner, G., Aiona, J., Sickler, W., Garrett, B., Lawler, K., Benavides, M., … Poulter, L. (2018, April 30). Schnall et al 2008 Student Replication.

description: Words that have higher ratings on the BOI measure receive faster responses (RTs) in lexical-semantic tasks (e.g., lexical decision, semantic decision). The BOI quantifies the ease with which the human body can physically interact with a word’s referent. The BOI effect is thought to show that sensorimotor information contributes to word meaning, providing support for embodied theories of semantic representation
tags: semantic richness, concepts, lexical processing, language, sensorimotor features, body-object interaction

ref_original: Tykocinski, O. E., Pittman, T. S., & Tuttle, E. E. (1995). Inaction inertia: Foregoing future benefits as a result of an initial failure to act. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 68(5), 793–803.

description: forgoing an initial attractive opportunity decreases the likelihood of taking a subsequent opportunity that is less attractive, even when the subsequent opportunity still offers positive value
tags: CORE, Judgment, Decision Making, JDM, Heuristics, Biases
